HERP.content: caught in ring of circle once questioning philosophy, engaged by Greek tongue > acc. Heidegger, obscurely, authoritatively, Greek tongue alone is logos
HERP.linkedContent: caught in ring of circle once questioning philosophy, engaged by Greek tongue > acc. Heidegger, obscurely, authoritatively, Greek tongue alone is logos

HERP.content: for Heidegger, anthropology & psychology depend on metaphysics of subjectivity, interpretation of man as subject; thus, psychology did not exist for Greeks, and Christianity (w/ its new relation to philein) is 1st stage in formation of passions for subject/psychology
HERP.linkedContent: for Heidegger, anthropology & psychology depend on metaphysics of subjectivity, interpretation of man as subject; thus, psychology did not exist for Greeks, and Christianity (w/ its new relation to philein) is 1st stage in formation of passions for subject/psychology

POOF.content: once Nietzsche goes beyond Greek friendship, can we find unity in Greek culture anymore? > when he says, “in honor of friendship,” he knows (better than anyone) he is speaking Greek
POOF.linkedContent: once Nietzsche goes beyond Greek friendship, can we find unity in Greek culture anymore? > when he says, “in honor of friendship,” he knows (better than anyone) he is speaking Greek

POOF.content: via Leroux, fraternity links freedom & equality OR fraternity appears first as origin/principle > Christianity as an ‘infinite enlargement’ of [gentle] fraternity, still deploys a Greek memory: these 2 memories efficiently coupled in ideal instant of French Revolution
POOF.linkedContent: via Leroux, fraternity links freedom & equality OR fraternity appears first as origin/principle > Christianity as an ‘infinite enlargement’ of [gentle] fraternity, still deploys a Greek memory: these 2 memories efficiently coupled in ideal instant of French Revolution

VM.content: Heidegger & Husserl’s untraditional appeal to tradition: entirety of philosophy on basis of Greek source, can’t philosophize outside this medium
VM.linkedContent: Heidegger & Husserl’s untraditional appeal to tradition: entirety of philosophy on basis of Greek source, can’t philosophize outside this medium

VM.content: that we are consigned to Greek element, a knowledge and confidence that is not comfortable, that torments us > Husserl’s crisis, a covering up of a transcendental motif beginning to accomplish Greek aim in Descartes & Kant: philosophy as science
VM.linkedContent: that we are consigned to Greek element, a knowledge and confidence that is not comfortable, that torments us > Husserl’s crisis, a covering up of a transcendental motif beginning to accomplish Greek aim in Descartes & Kant: philosophy as science

VM.content: Heidegger says our thought has been desiccated, its return to Greek source, thought of Being, is a knowledge, security not in the world, possibility of our language & nexus of our world
VM.linkedContent: Heidegger says our thought has been desiccated, its return to Greek source, thought of Being, is a knowledge, security not in the world, possibility of our language & nexus of our world

VM.content: can the other of the Greek be named non-Greek? pensée pour laquelle le tout du logos grec est déjà survenu (erupted), humus apaisé non pas sur un sol, mais autour d’un volcan plus anicen
VM.linkedContent: can the other of the Greek be named non-Greek? pensée pour laquelle le tout du logos grec est déjà survenu (erupted), humus apaisé non pas sur un sol, mais autour d’un volcan plus anicen

VM.content: Levinas seeks a second parricide, to murder the Greek father (who still holds us in his sway), a father Plato could only hallucinate murdering, “a hallucination within the hallucination that is already speech” > could a non-Greek succeed in doing what a Greek could never do? and do so by feigning to speak Greek, can one feign to speak a language?
VM.linkedContent: Levinas seeks a second parricide, to murder the Greek father (who still holds us in his sway), a father Plato could only hallucinate murdering, “a hallucination within the hallucination that is already speech” > could a non-Greek succeed in doing what a Greek could never do? and do so by feigning to speak Greek, can one feign to speak a language?

VM.content: [Derrida on philology of other > autrui (substantive that’s not a noun), autre, heteron, alter-huic > what does autre mean before Greek heteron? before Judeo-Christian autrui?]
VM.linkedContent: [Derrida on philology of other > autrui (substantive that’s not a noun), autre, heteron, alter-huic > what does autre mean before Greek heteron? before Judeo-Christian autrui?]

VM.content: why does Levinas return to categories he rejected? Derrida’s not denouncing incoherence [w/ this question], he’s wondering about meaning of necessity, necessity of lodging oneself w/in traditional conceptuality in order to destroy it—does this imposed necessity cache-t-elle quelque ressource indestructible et imprévisible du logos grec? quelque puissance illimitée d’enveloppement dans laquelle celui qui voudrait le repousser serait toujours déjà surpris?
VM.linkedContent: why does Levinas return to categories he rejected? Derrida’s not denouncing incoherence [w/ this question], he’s wondering about meaning of necessity, necessity of lodging oneself w/in traditional conceptuality in order to destroy it—does this imposed necessity cache-t-elle quelque ressource indestructible et imprévisible du logos grec? quelque puissance illimitée d’enveloppement dans laquelle celui qui voudrait le repousser serait toujours déjà surpris?

VM.content: question “why finitude?” can be stated only by being forgotten in language of Greeks
VM.linkedContent: question “why finitude?” can be stated only by being forgotten in language of Greeks

VM.content: nothing can so profoundly solicit Greek logos [& reawaken it to its mortality, its other] as irruption of tout-autre > Greek language offers hospitality to a thought which remains foreign to it [Jew/Christian in his home]
VM.linkedContent: nothing can so profoundly solicit Greek logos [& reawaken it to its mortality, its other] as irruption of tout-autre > Greek language offers hospitality to a thought which remains foreign to it [Jew/Christian in his home]

VM.content: Greek logos not accidental for any thought; Greek miracle is impossibility for any thought to treat its sages as “sages of the outside” > by proferring epekeina tes ousias, by welcoming alterity into heart of logos, it has protected itself against every surprising convocation
VM.linkedContent: Greek logos not accidental for any thought; Greek miracle is impossibility for any thought to treat its sages as “sages of the outside” > by proferring epekeina tes ousias, by welcoming alterity into heart of logos, it has protected itself against every surprising convocation

VM.content: to live in difference btwn Jew and Greek, perhaps the unity we call history
VM.linkedContent: to live in difference btwn Jew and Greek, perhaps the unity we call history

VM.content: Greek logos provides understanding to those who understand eschatological prophecy and to those who don’t
VM.linkedContent: Greek logos provides understanding to those who understand eschatological prophecy and to those who don’t

S.content: Heidegger: Greek language and reflection, along w/ German, most powerful and spiritual language
S.linkedContent: Heidegger: Greek language and reflection, along w/ German, most powerful and spiritual language

S.content: for Heidegger, signature of thought never individual, commits via community, people, in his or her own language; there are only some languages open to Being: German, Greek
S.linkedContent: for Heidegger, signature of thought never individual, commits via community, people, in his or her own language; there are only some languages open to Being: German, Greek

S.content: Derrida imagines how Greeks would have responded to Heidegger’s claim about their pneuma via Geist > imagines they would claim prerogative of Greek
S.linkedContent: Derrida imagines how Greeks would have responded to Heidegger’s claim about their pneuma via Geist > imagines they would claim prerogative of Greek

FWT.content: rigorously, “philosophy” exists nowhere other than in Greece, yet it tends toward liberating itself from this cultural limitation, will toward deracination [Husserl, Heidegger]
FWT.linkedContent: rigorously, “philosophy” exists nowhere other than in Greece, yet it tends toward liberating itself from this cultural limitation, will toward deracination [Husserl, Heidegger]

FWT.content: the universal of philosophy (neither relativism nor nationalism) not a given, an essence, but an infinite process of universalization > in the name of European filiation we are liberating ourselves from Eurocentrism/ethnocentrism
FWT.linkedContent: the universal of philosophy (neither relativism nor nationalism) not a given, an essence, but an infinite process of universalization > in the name of European filiation we are liberating ourselves from Eurocentrism/ethnocentrism

HASD.content: Christianity did not cease to be Greek [both are apophatic, only Christianity is evental?]
HASD.linkedContent: Christianity did not cease to be Greek [both are apophatic, only Christianity is evental?]

SW.content: God as name of what gives the order to give the veil (btwn holy & holy of holies), veil as gift (that it is) ordered to give, gives to think separation from le tout autre (faith itself) > did this come to an end w/ death of Christ? can it be comprehended in veiled folds of Greek alētheia?
SW.linkedContent: God as name of what gives the order to give the veil (btwn holy & holy of holies), veil as gift (that it is) ordered to give, gives to think separation from le tout autre (faith itself) > did this come to an end w/ death of Christ? can it be comprehended in veiled folds of Greek alētheia?

CHM.content: Foucault’s bothersome idea re: Greek logos: it “had no contrary” > [Derrida wonders if there is already a dissension btwn madness & reason, a founding unity that already carries w/in it “free trade” of Medieval Ages]
CHM.linkedContent: Foucault’s bothersome idea re: Greek logos: it “had no contrary” > [Derrida wonders if there is already a dissension btwn madness & reason, a founding unity that already carries w/in it “free trade” of Medieval Ages]

CHM.content: historico-philosophical motivations for Nietzsche’s/Heidegger’s fascination w/ pre-Socratics still to be examined (mystification)
CHM.linkedContent: historico-philosophical motivations for Nietzsche’s/Heidegger’s fascination w/ pre-Socratics still to be examined (mystification)

WOG.content: my relationship to ‘Greece’ is somewhat naive, limited by philological & historical incompetence
WOG.linkedContent: my relationship to ‘Greece’ is somewhat naive, limited by philological & historical incompetence

WOG.content: horizon of Greek thing itself no longer assured in Derrida: neither as place, system of language, spiritual figure (‘Husserl’) or historial figure (‘Heidegger’)
WOG.linkedContent: horizon of Greek thing itself no longer assured in Derrida: neither as place, system of language, spiritual figure (‘Husserl’) or historial figure (‘Heidegger’)

WOG.content: on the use of Greek words [in Foucault, Heidegger, Kuhn, Holton]: 1) new concept not in everyday language 2) new archeological discovery: restoration 3) authority of rare words
WOG.linkedContent: on the use of Greek words [in Foucault, Heidegger, Kuhn, Holton]: 1) new concept not in everyday language 2) new archeological discovery: restoration 3) authority of rare words

WOG.content: ontology could not be more Greek, toward which Derrida has had only questions, reservations, and interminable parentheses
WOG.linkedContent: ontology could not be more Greek, toward which Derrida has had only questions, reservations, and interminable parentheses

WOG.content: Derrida took from Greeks: other of language, simulacrum, infinite alterity, while privileging epekeina tēs ousias, that which uproots ontology and metaphysics
WOG.linkedContent: Derrida took from Greeks: other of language, simulacrum, infinite alterity, while privileging epekeina tēs ousias, that which uproots ontology and metaphysics

WOG.content: the remainder (of all ontology) and the contamination btwn tout autre and its regular reappropriation (economic redialectization) haunts all Derrida’s essays on the Greeks
WOG.linkedContent: the remainder (of all ontology) and the contamination btwn tout autre and its regular reappropriation (economic redialectization) haunts all Derrida’s essays on the Greeks

WOG.content: the tout autre of the Greek, the figure of a tout autre unfigurable by him
WOG.linkedContent: the tout autre of the Greek, the figure of a tout autre unfigurable by him

WOG.content: deconstruction at work in the ‘origin,’ already from the ‘origin’ itself—upon deconstruction of the origin
WOG.linkedContent: deconstruction at work in the ‘origin,’ already from the ‘origin’ itself—upon deconstruction of the origin

WOG.content: Greeks definitely speak the truth, but at what cost, under what conditions?
WOG.linkedContent: Greeks definitely speak the truth, but at what cost, under what conditions?

WOG.content: mediation through Nietzsche [re: Greeks] not constant—often ironic; PC very ironic about Nietzsche’s image of Socrates
WOG.linkedContent: mediation through Nietzsche [re: Greeks] not constant—often ironic; PC very ironic about Nietzsche’s image of Socrates

WOG.content: impossibility to read/translate Greek means those works can’t close upon themselves, already marked by irruption of other [an experience already there for the “original” Greeks]
WOG.linkedContent: impossibility to read/translate Greek means those works can’t close upon themselves, already marked by irruption of other [an experience already there for the “original” Greeks]

WOG.content: undecidability found a certain privilege in ‘Greek’ words, in philosophy, on [sur?] its borders, that is, beyond its confines [pharmakon, hymen, parergon]
WOG.linkedContent: undecidability found a certain privilege in ‘Greek’ words, in philosophy, on [sur?] its borders, that is, beyond its confines [pharmakon, hymen, parergon]

WOG.content: Wolff & Alliez, when defining Derrida’s Greek inheritance, neglect relation btwn khōra and epekeina tēs ousias
WOG.linkedContent: Wolff & Alliez, when defining Derrida’s Greek inheritance, neglect relation btwn khōra and epekeina tēs ousias

WOG.content: hen diapheron heautôi (Heraclitus) is Greek heritage Derrida is most faithful to, tries to think this “one differing from itself” alongside (“improbably”) the khōra > the very event of the même, the soi-même: under this sign, Derrida contrasted differance to ontological difference [cf. DIF p. 22]
WOG.linkedContent: hen diapheron heautôi (Heraclitus) is Greek heritage Derrida is most faithful to, tries to think this “one differing from itself” alongside (“improbably”) the khōra > the very event of the même, the soi-même: under this sign, Derrida contrasted differance to ontological difference [cf. DIF p. 22]

OG.content: totality of metaphysics creates hierarchy of signifier/signified [signified is higher, not exterior like signifier] (Christian creationism, infinitism, both appropriating Greek conceptualism)
OG.linkedContent: totality of metaphysics creates hierarchy of signifier/signified [signified is higher, not exterior like signifier] (Christian creationism, infinitism, both appropriating Greek conceptualism)
